ext_sysfile.h

00001 
00002 #ifndef _SYSFILE_H_
00003 #define _SYSFILE_H_
00004 
00005 
00006 
00007 /** A t_filehandle is a cross-platform way of referring to an open file.
00008     It is an opaque structure, meaning you don’t have access to the individual 
00009     elements of the data structure. You can use a t_filehandle only 
00010     with the file routines in the Sysfile API. Do not use other platform- 
00011     specific file functions in conjunction with these functions. 
00012     The perm parameter can be either READ_PERM, WRITE_PERM, or RW_PERM.
00013 
00014     @ingroup files */
00015 typedef void *t_filehandle;
00016 
00017 
00018 /** Modes used by sysfile_setpos()
00019     @ingroup files */
00020 typedef enum {
00021     SYSFILE_ATMARK = 0,     ///< ?
00022     SYSFILE_FROMSTART,      ///< Calculate the file position from the start of the file.
00023     SYSFILE_FROMLEOF,       ///< Calculate the file position from the logical end of the file.
00024     SYSFILE_FROMMARK        ///< Calculate the file position from the current file position.
00025 } e_max_sysfile_posmodes;
00026 
00027 
00028 /** Flags used reading and writing text files.
00029     @ingroup files */
00030 typedef enum {
00031     TEXT_LB_NATIVE =            0x00000001L,    ///< Use the linebreak format native to the current platform.
00032     TEXT_LB_MAC =               0x00000002L,    ///< Use Macintosh line breaks
00033     TEXT_LB_PC =                0x00000004L,    ///< Use Windows line breaks
00034     TEXT_LB_UNIX =              0x00000008L,    ///< Use Unix line breaks
00035     TEXT_ENCODING_USE_FILE =    0x00000100L     ///< If this flag is not set then the encoding is forced to UTF8
00036 } e_max_sysfile_textflags;
00037 
00038 
00039 #ifdef __cplusplus
00040 extern "C" {
00041 #endif
00042 
00043 
00044 /** Close a file opened with sysfile_open().
00045     This function is similar to FSClose() or fclose(). 
00046     It should be used instead of system-specific file closing routines in order to make max external 
00047     code that will compile cross-platform. 
00048     
00049     @ingroup    files
00050     @param  f   The #t_filehandle structure of the file the user wants to close. 
00051     @return     An error code.
00052 */
00053 extern long sysfile_close(t_filehandle f);
00054 
00055 
00056 /** Read a file from disk.
00057     This function is similar to FSRead() or fread(). It should be used instead of 
00058     these functions (or other system-specific file reading routines) in order 
00059     to make max external code that will compile cross-platform. It reads 
00060     “count” bytes from file handle at current file position into “bufptr”. 
00061     The byte count actually read is set in “count”, and the file position is 
00062     updated by the actual byte count read.
00063 
00064     @ingroup files
00065     @param  f       The #t_filehandle structure of the file the user wants to open.
00066     @param  count   Pointer to the number of bytes that will be read from the file at the current file position. 
00067                     The byte count actually read is returned to this value.
00068     @param  bufptr  Pointer to the buffer that the data will be read into.
00069     @return         An error code.
00070 */
00071 extern long sysfile_read(t_filehandle f, long *count, void *bufptr);
00072 
00073 
00074 /** Read the contents of a file into a handle.
00075     @ingroup files
00076     @param  f   The open #t_filehandle structure to read into the handle.
00077     @param  h   The address of a handle into which the file will be read.
00078     @return     An error code.
00079     @remark     You should free the pointer, when you are done with it, using sysmem_freehandle().
00080 */
00081 extern long sysfile_readtohandle(t_filehandle f, char ***h);
00082 
00083 
00084 /** Read the contents of a file into a pointer.
00085     @ingroup files
00086     @param  f   The open #t_filehandle structure to read into the handle.
00087     @param  p   The address of a pointer into which the file will be read.
00088     @return     An error code.
00089     @remark     You should free the pointer, when you are done with it, using sysmem_freeptr().
00090 */
00091 extern long sysfile_readtoptr(t_filehandle f, char **p);
00092 
00093 
00094 /** Write part of a file to disk.
00095     This function is similar to FSWrite() or fwrite(). It should be used instead 
00096     of these functions (or other system-specific file reading routines) in 
00097     order to make max external code that will compile cross-platform. The 
00098     function writes “count” bytes from “bufptr” into file handle at current 
00099     file position. The byte count actually written is set in "count", and the
00100     file position is updated by the actual byte count written.
00101 
00102     @ingroup files
00103     @param  f       The t_filehandle structure of the file to which the user wants to write.
00104     @param  count   Pointer to the number of bytes that will be written to the file at the current file position. 
00105                     The byte count actually written is returned to this value.
00106     @param  bufptr  Pointer to the buffer that the data will be read from. 
00107     @return         An error code.
00108 */
00109 extern long sysfile_write(t_filehandle f, long *count, const void *bufptr);
00110 
00111 
00112 /** Set the size of a file handle.
00113     This function is similar to and should be used instead of SetEOF(). 
00114     The function sets the size of file handle in bytes, specified by “logeof”. 
00115     
00116     @ingroup        files
00117     @param  f       The file's #t_filehandle structure.
00118     @param  logeof  The file size in bytes.
00119     @return         An error code.
00120 */
00121 extern long sysfile_seteof(t_filehandle f, long logeof);
00122 
00123 
00124 /** Get the size of a file handle.
00125     This function is similar to and should be used instead of GetEOF().
00126     The function gets the size of file handle in bytes, and places it in “logeof”. 
00127     
00128     @ingroup        files
00129     @param  f       The file's #t_filehandle structure.
00130     @param  logeof  The file size in bytes is returned to this value.
00131     @return         An error code.
00132 */
00133 extern long sysfile_geteof(t_filehandle f, long *logeof);
00134 
00135 
00136 /** Set the current file position of a file handle.
00137     This function is similar to and should be used instead of SetFPos(). 
00138     It is used to set the current file position of file handle to by the given 
00139     number of offset bytes relative to the mode used, as defined in #e_max_sysfile_posmodes.
00140     
00141     @ingroup        files
00142     @param  f       The file's #t_filehandle structure.
00143     @param  mode    Mode from which the offset will be calculated, as defined in #e_max_sysfile_posmodes.
00144     @param  offset  The offset in bytes relative to the mode.
00145     @return         An error code.
00146 */
00147 extern long sysfile_setpos(t_filehandle f, long mode, long offset);
00148 
00149 
00150 /** Get the current file position of a file handle.
00151     This function is similar to and should be used instead of GetFPos(). 
00152     The function gets the current file position of file handle in bytes, and places it in "filepos". 
00153     
00154     @ingroup        files
00155     @param  f       The file's #t_filehandle structure.
00156     @param  filepos The address of a variable to hold the current file position of file handle in bytes. 
00157     @return         An error code.
00158 */
00159 extern long sysfile_getpos(t_filehandle f, long *filepos);
00160 
00161 
00162 /** Copy the contents of one file handle to another file handle.
00163     @ingroup files
00164     @param  src     The file handle from which to copy.
00165     @param  dst     The file handle to which the copy is written.
00166     @param  size    The number of bytes to copy.  If 0 the size of src will be used.
00167     @return         An error code.
00168 */
00169 long sysfile_spoolcopy(t_filehandle src, t_filehandle dst, long size);
00170 
00171 
00172 // private
00173 void sysfile_setobject(t_filehandle f, t_object *o);
00174 
00175 
00176 
00177 /** Read a text file from disk.
00178     This function reads up to the maximum number of bytes given by 
00179     maxlen from file handle at current file position into the htext 
00180     handle, performing linebreak translation if set in flags.
00181 
00182     @ingroup        files
00183     @param  f       The #t_filehandle structure of the text file the user wants to open.
00184     @param  htext   Handle that the data will be read into.
00185     @param  maxlen  The maximum length in bytes to be read into the handle. 
00186                     Passing the value 0L indicates no maximum (i.e. read the entire file).
00187     @param  flags   Flags to set linebreak translation as defined in #e_max_sysfile_textflags.
00188     @return         An error code.
00189 */
00190 extern long sysfile_readtextfile(t_filehandle f, t_handle htext, long maxlen, long flags);
00191 
00192 
00193 /** Write a text file to disk.
00194     This function writes a text handle to a text file performing linebreak 
00195     translation if set in flags.
00196 
00197     @ingroup        files
00198     @param  f       The #t_filehandle structure of the text file to which the user wants to write.
00199     @param  htext   Handle that the data that will be read from.
00200     @param  flags   Flags to set linebreak translation as defined in #e_max_sysfile_textflags.
00201     @return         An error code.
00202 */
00203 extern long sysfile_writetextfile(t_filehandle f, t_handle htext, long flags);
00204 
00205 
00206 /** Create a #t_filehandle from a pre-existing handle.
00207     @ingroup    files   
00208     @param      h       A handle for some data.
00209     @param      flags   Pass 0 (additional flags are private).
00210     @param      fh      The address of a #t_filehandle which will be allocated.
00211     @return             An error code.
00212 */
00213 short sysfile_openhandle(char **h, long flags, t_filehandle *fh);
00214 
00215 
00216 /** Create a #t_filehandle from a pre-existing pointer.
00217     @ingroup    files   
00218     @param      p       A pointer to some data.
00219     @param      length  The size of p.
00220     @param      flags   Pass 0 (additional flags are private).
00221     @param      fh      The address of a #t_filehandle which will be allocated.
00222     @return             An error code.
00223 */
00224 short sysfile_openptrsize(char *p, long length, long flags, t_filehandle *fh);

00227 #ifdef __cplusplus
00228 }

00231 #endif // _SYSFILE_H_
